title: How to Turn a Plastic Soda Bottle Into a Coin Purse

steps.headline: Find 2 plastic bottles to use as a coin purse.
steps.description: The bottles need to be the same shape and size. It would be best if they are the same color, but you can use different colors if you want to, such as clear and green. A small water bottle or soda bottle will work the best for this. You can also use a 2-liter (67-oz) bottle for a large coin purse.

steps.headline: Cut the bottom portion off of each bottle, then discard the top.
steps.description: Most bottles will have a molded line just below the label. Cut ⁄2 to 1 inch (1.3 to 2.5 cm) above this line. This way, you will have room to clean up the cut edges. You can do this with a pair of scissors or a craft blade. Recycle the top portion of each bottle.

steps.headline: Trim the cut edge further to clean up any jaggedness.
steps.description: Use a pair of scissors to cut along the cut edge of each bottle half. Cut all the way down to the molded line. If you need to, use a piece of sandpaper or a nail file to smooth down any jagged edges.

steps.headline: Clean the inside of the bottle halves, if needed.
steps.description: Wash the inside of each bottle half with soap and warm water. Rinse them, then dry them with a towel. Be sure to remove any labels or sticker residue. Skip this step if you used water bottles. They won't be sticky like soda bottles. It is better to clean bottles after you cut them. The opening is larger, making it easier to reach inside.

steps.headline: Punch holes along the cut edges with a thick needle.
steps.description: Find a thick needle or a metal awl. Punch holes about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) apart along the cut edge of each bottle. Make the holes about ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) from the cut edge. Any needle that is thick and sharp will work the best for this. Consider leather needles, repair needles, or heavy-duty sewing needles. Don't make the holes too far from the cut edge of the bottle, or you won't be able to sew the zipper on.

steps.headline: Find a zipper that is long enough to wrap around the bottle.
steps.description: Measure around 1 of the bottle halves with a measuring tape, then go to the fabric store or craft store. Buy a zipper that is at least the same length as your measurement. Remember, it is better to buy a longer zipper; you can always cut it down. If you don't have a measuring tape, wrap a piece of string around the bottle instead, then measure it against a ruler.

steps.headline: Place the zipper inside the bottle, along the cut edge.
steps.description: Hold the zipper inside the bottle so that the teeth are touching the cut edge. Secure the zipper starting from the bottom with sewing pins or pieces of tape. Don't worry about the other side of the zipper for now. The bottom of the zipper tape is where you pull in order to open it. The top of the zipper is where you pull towards in order to close it. You can leave the zipper closed or open for this step, whichever is easier for you.

steps.headline: Overlap the ends of the zipper if the zipper is too long.
steps.description: Finish positioning the zipper first. Place the top of the zipper tape behind the bottom of the zipper tape to create an overlap. Secure the overlap with a piece of tape or a sewing pin.

steps.headline: Thread your needle with strong thread.
steps.description: Choose a thread color that matches the zipper tape; you can also use clear thread. Push thread through the eye of your needle, then tie both ends of the thread together in a knot. This will create a double-strand of thread, which will be stronger than a single-strand. You can use the same needle that you used to punch the holes, or you can use a thinner needle.

steps.headline: Sew the zipper to the bottle using a running stitch.
steps.description: Start sewing from inside the bottle at the bottom of the zipper. Weave the needle up and down through the punched holes and zipper tape. Knot the thread inside the bottle when you reach the other end of the zipper. Remove the pins or pieces of tape as you sew.

steps.headline: Open the zipper and sew it to the other half of the bottle.
steps.description: If you have not already, punch holes along the cut edge of the second bottle half. Sew the other side of the zipper to the inside of the bottle using the same technique as before. Be aware that the first half of the coin purse may make this step a little awkward. Make sure that the zipper teeth are touching the cut edge of the bottle!

steps.headline: Zip the bottle shut.
steps.description: Your coin purse is now complete and ready to use! If you want to decorate the coin purse, continue on to the next section.

steps.headline: Choose 1 to 2 decorations for your coin purse.
steps.description: When it comes to decorating, less is often more. If you add too many decorations, your coin purse will look cluttered and messy. Instead, choose 1 or 2 decorating methods. Be careful not to cover the zipper teeth, however!

steps.headline: Hot glue ribbon to the edges if you want to hide the zipper tape.
steps.description: Find a ribbon wide enough to cover the zipper tape. Hot glue the ribbon around the top edge of each bottle half, just below the zipper teeth. Cut the ends of the ribbon and glue them down. Make sure that you are gluing the ribbon to the outside of the bottles, otherwise it won't cover the zipper tape.

steps.headline: Use patterned tape if you don't want to use ribbon.
steps.description: Find some patterned washi tape that is wide enough to cover the zipper tape. Wrap it around the outside of the bottle, just below the zipper teeth. Cut the end of the tape, and press it down. Do this for both halves of the coin purse. You can find washi tape in the scrapbooking section of a craft store.

steps.headline: Hot glue large googly eyes if you want a cartoon effect.
steps.description: Buy a set of large googly eyes. Hot glue them to the top half of your coin purse. This works great for green coin purses--it will make it look like a frog! Give your coin purse more personality by hot gluing felt shapes to make a mouth or ears!

steps.headline: Decorate your coin purse with stickers if you want a colorful look.
steps.description: Buy a pack of stickers from the craft store. Choose a few stickers that you like, peel them off, and press them against the coin purse. Simple stickers, such as hearts or stars, work the best.

steps.headline: Glue rhinestones to your coin purse if you want a sparkly look.
steps.description: Get a pack of rhinestones from the craft store and glue them to the coin purse. Super glue will work the best, but you can try using small amounts of hot glue as well. Experiment with large and small rhinestones. You should glue self-adhesive rhinestones as well. The adhesive is not very strong compared to super glue.

steps.headline: Paint the coin purse if you don't like the color.
steps.description: Buff the surface of the coin purse with fine-grit sandpaper. Wipe the surface down with rubbing alcohol, then paint it using acrylic craft paint. Let the paint dry 15 to 20 minutes, then add a second coat. Let the paint dry completely before using it. A fine-grit sandpaper that's between 120 and 180 will work the best for this. Buffing the coin purse will give the paint something to stick to. The rubbing alcohol will clean it and help the paint stick better. You can use spray paint, but close the purse first. Be aware that this will also change the color of the zipper.

steps.headline: Draw designs with permanent markers for something simple.
steps.description: Wipe the surface of the coin purse down with rubbing alcohol; this will help the ink stick better. Draw your desired designs using permanent markers on the outside of the coin purse. This works best on clear plastic; permanent markers are translucent. You can try using paint pens on colored plastic, but be aware that the paint may bead.

It would be best if they are the same color, but you can use different colors if you want to, such as clear and green. A small water bottle or soda bottle will work the best for this. You can also use a 2-liter (67-oz) bottle for a large coin purse. Cut the bottom portion off of each bottle, then discard the top. Most bottles will have a molded line just below the label. Cut ⁄2 to 1 inch (1.3 to 2.5 cm) above this line. This way, you will have room to clean up the cut edges. You can do this with a pair of scissors or a craft blade. They won't be sticky like soda bottles. It is better to clean bottles after you cut them. The opening is larger, making it easier to reach inside. This will create a double-strand of thread, which will be stronger than a single-strand. You can use the same needle that you used to punch the holes, or you can use a thinner needle. Be aware that the first half of the coin purse may make this step a little awkward. Make sure that the zipper teeth are touching the cut edge of the bottle! Zip the bottle shut. The adhesive is not very strong compared to super glue. Paint the coin purse if you don't like the color. Buff the surface of the coin purse with fine-grit sandpaper.
